verses.text: When you sit to eat with a ruler, carefully consider what is before you,
verses.comment: Wisdom exercises prudence even amid abundance. The table imagery recalls Psalm 23:5, highlighting divine provision.

verses.text: Put a knife to your throat if you are given to appetite.
verses.comment: A vivid warning against gluttony and lack of self-control. Jesus Himself warns His followers about excess (Luke 21:34).

verses.text: Do not desire his delicacies, for they are deceptive food.
verses.comment: Fleeting pleasures can ensnare the soul. The call is for detachment from worldly allurements—a theme echoed by St. Paul (1 Timothy 6:9-10).

verses.text: Do not labor to gain riches; cease from your own understanding.
verses.comment: Prioritizing wealth over wisdom is condemned. Jesus urges seeking the Kingdom first (Matthew 6:33). Spiritual wisdom surpasses material wealth.

verses.text: Will you set your eyes upon it, when it is gone? For riches certainly make themselves wings; they fly away like an eagle toward heaven.
verses.comment: A reminder of the fleeting nature of riches, paralleling Jesus' teaching about treasures in heaven (Matthew 6:19-20).

verses.text: Do not eat the bread of one with an evil eye, nor desire his delicacies.
verses.comment: An 'evil eye' signifies envy and stinginess. The verse urges discernment of motives. Jesus addresses similar themes (Matthew 20:15).

verses.text: For as he calculates in his heart, so is he. 'Eat and drink,' he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
verses.comment: True intentions matter more than outward appearances—a theme emphasized in Christ’s teachings (Matthew 15:8).

verses.text: You will vomit up the morsel you have eaten and waste your pleasant words.
verses.comment: Dishonest hospitality will ultimately leave you empty and dissatisfied. Spiritual purity is highlighted.

verses.text: Do not speak in the hearing of a fool, for he will despise the wisdom of your words.
verses.comment: Jesus warns about casting pearls before swine (Matthew 7:6). The wise must discern suitable audiences for instruction.

verses.text: Do not move the ancient boundary stone or enter the fields of the fatherless;
verses.comment: Respecting property and the vulnerable recalls the Law's commandment for justice, reflecting the call to care for orphans and widows (James 1:27).

verses.text: For their Redeemer is mighty; he will plead their cause against you.
verses.comment: The mighty Redeemer here foreshadows Christ, Defender of the oppressed. The theme of intercession is prominent across Scripture.

verses.text: Apply your heart to instruction, and your ears to words of knowledge.
verses.comment: Commitment to wisdom requires wholehearted effort. Spiritual formation through discipline is stressed.

verses.text: Do not withhold correction from a child; if you discipline him with the rod, he will not die.
verses.comment: Proper discipline is formative, not destructive. Recalling Hebrews 12:6's 'God disciplines those He loves'.

verses.text: You shall discipline him with the rod and rescue his soul from Sheol.
verses.comment: Discipline of the young has soteriological dimensions; correction leads away from spiritual death.

verses.text: My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will rejoice—indeed, I myself;
verses.comment: A father’s joy is linked to the spiritual wisdom and virtue of his child—a reflection of God the Father's own love.

verses.text: And my innermost being will exult, when your lips speak what is right.
verses.comment: Spiritual joy comes when children walk in truth. Parallels the deep joy God feels at His children's righteousness.

verses.text: Do not let your heart envy sinners, but continue in the fear of the LORD all day.
verses.comment: Echoes Psalm 37. The 'fear of the Lord' is a theme which runs throughout Scripture and aligns both literal and spiritual interpretation.

verses.text: For surely there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
verses.comment: Points to a secure eschatological hope, foreshadowing the eternal life Christ offers.

verses.text: Hear, my son, and be wise, and direct your heart on the right path.
verses.comment: Spiritual formation requires choosing and maintaining the right path—a metaphor for moral and spiritual progress.

verses.text: Do not be among drunkards or among those who feast on meat,
verses.comment: Temperance is praised, contrasting those who surrender to sensual appetites. Abstinence is a recurring biblical virtue.

verses.text: For the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, and drowsiness will clothe a man with rags.
verses.comment: Vice leads to ruin. The theme of discipline points to virtuous living as modeled by the saints.

verses.text: Listen to your father who gave you life, and do not despise your mother when she is old.
verses.comment: Honoring parents recalls the commandment (Exodus 20:12); obedience and familial piety are core to spiritual life.

verses.text: Buy truth, and do not sell it—wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
verses.comment: Truth and wisdom are worth every sacrifice, much like the parable of the pearl of great price. There is a sacrificial aspect to attaining spiritual wisdom.

verses.text: The father of the righteous will greatly rejoice; he who fathers a wise son will delight in him.
verses.comment: Righteousness causes both earthly and heavenly delight, echoing the Father's pleasure in His Son (Matthew 3:17).

verses.text: Let your father and mother be glad; let her who bore you rejoice.
verses.comment: A reaffirmation about the joy brought to parents by wise and righteous children. Godly families are the foundation of faith communities.

verses.text: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways.
verses.comment: Wholehearted devotion and imitation of godly examples point to later calls for discipleship in the New Testament.

verses.text: For a prostitute is a deep pit, and a wayward woman is a narrow well;
verses.comment: Sexual immorality is a recurring danger in Proverbs, showing the destructive power of sin.

verses.text: She lies in wait like a robber, and increases the faithless among men.
verses.comment: Immorality leads to spiritual ruin and erodes the foundation of faithful living.

verses.text: Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has strife? Who has complaints? Who has wounds without cause? Who has red eyes?
verses.comment: The rhetorical questions prepare the reader for a warning about drunkenness and vice.

verses.text: Those who linger long over wine, those who go in search of mixed wine.
verses.comment: Excessive drinking is condemned. Self-mastery is crucial in the spiritual life.

verses.text: Do not look at wine when it sparkles red in the cup, when it moves smoothly.
verses.comment: Warning against temptation and seduction of the senses. Spiritual vigilance is required.

verses.text: At the last it bites like a serpent and stings like a viper.
verses.comment: Consequences of sin are often hidden, but ultimately bring suffering—recalling Genesis 3's serpent and spiritual warfare.

verses.text: Your eyes will see strange things, and your heart will utter perverse things.
verses.comment: Loss of spiritual clarity follows indulgence in vice. By contrast, spiritual sobriety leads to truth.

verses.text: You will be like one who lies down in the middle of the sea, or like one who lies on top of a mast.
verses.comment: Imagery of instability and danger, showing the consequences of abandoning wisdom. The sea also symbolizes chaos.

verses.text: They struck me, you will say, and I was not hurt; they beat me, but I did not feel it. When shall I awake? I will seek it again.
verses.comment: Final warning about addiction and lack of self-control. Only grace can break the cycle and bring restoration. Deeper spiritual realities are hinted at regarding habitual sin.
